section.title: Fitting Peak-Over-Thresholds Models
section.para: In some cases, it may be desirable to analytically fit a probability distribution to POT data. Two general approaches have been used.

In the first approach, the annual flow series distribution has been estimated from the POT series on the basis that the latter considers all of the relevant data and should thus provide a better estimate. The basis for the procedure is , which links Poisson arrivals of flood peaks with a distribution of flood magnitudes above some threshold. b3_c2_r39+1, b3_c2_r7+1 and b3_c2_r72+1 explored this approach using the exponential distribution. The approach has been fairly successful, but some results have diverged from the distribution derived directly from the annual series. Given the concern that the fit to the right tail of the annual maximum series may be compromised by the leverage exerted by the low flows, this approach cannot be recommended as a replacement for the analysis of annual series data. If possible, the base discharge for this approach should be selected so that the number of floods in the POT series m is at least 2 to 3 times the number of years of record n. However, it may be necessary to use a much lower value of m in regions with low rainfall where the number of recorded events that could be considered as floods is low.

The second approach uses a probability distribution as an arbitrary means of providing a consistent and objective fit to POT series data. For example, b3_c2_r51+1, b3_c2_r2+1 and b3_c2_r39+1 used the LP III distribution â€“ they found that selecting a threshold discharge such that m equalled n was best. illustrates this approach using L-moments to fit an exponential distribution to a POT series.
